title: Understanding Absolute Error
text: When adding two measurements, the absolute error is the sum of the individual absolute errors. This is because each measurement contributes its own uncertainty to the final result.

title: What is Absolute Error?
text: Absolute error is the uncertainty in a measurement, expressed in the same units as the measurement itself. It represents the range within which the true value is expected to lie.

title: Calculating Total Absolute Error
text: If you have two measurements, A and B, with absolute errors of ΔA and ΔB respectively, how do you calculate the total absolute error when adding these measurements?

title: Why Add Absolute Errors?
text: Adding absolute errors accounts for the maximum possible deviation in the final result due to the uncertainties in each measurement. This ensures that the calculated result is as accurate as possible.
